posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked:
Hello!

Our team is using Swerve and Pathplanner for the first time this year. At a test event today we attempted some autos to  see it going short to where its supposed to go.  It was meant to go from Reef to Feed Station but it only ended up moving almost a foot before stopping. In the Feild2d it showed it where its supposed to be. Has anyone else had this problem and if so how did you fix it?   Heres our code just in case.

link_counts.title: GitHub - MCRobotics7045/Robot-Source-Code-2025-Reefscape: code code and some PIDs here and there

posts.name: Steve
posts.cooked: This could be caused by a lot of different things. I would check that all of your constants/values are set correctly in your code and/or in pathplanner, e.g. gear ratios, current limits, wheel radius, etc

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
This value is really big! You should measure this.

Then tune these values. Also make sure you have correct pathplanner GUI config. Also if you want to make path-on-the-fly you need to have good odometry. So you should have a camera for apriltag tracking.

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: question. How would i measure the kSpeedat12Volts. and is there any tips you can give to tune the PID values

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
You can found detailed descriptions in advantagekit docs (If you are using this template, it will be easier. If not, try just getting the necessary values ​​into the smart dashboard and measure.)

Also wheel radius is important. Check wheel radius in the code.

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: Would it be possible for me to deploy the TalonFX template to my robot. Find the numbers then apply it to my other Code to get it tuned?

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
yes it should work. as template said, pid values is different then normal template. So you can measure max speed, slip current, custom wheel radius config. But for others I think you have to use advantage kit template’s code or you can adapt to your code(default ctre code if I don’t remember wrong has sysID tests for tuning). Generally True max speed is likely to be between 4.3 and 5.

make sure read setup. image 1115×598 49.5 KB

image 1115×598 49.5 KB

image 1115×598 49.5 KB

I also recommend using the advantage kit for the next season. I think it makes both debugging and simulation easier. It may be a bit difficult to learn, but once you learn it, it’s easy and worth it especially considering that programming is usually short on time (at least for us).

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked:
So far thanks for the help. But i attempted to deploy Templte code get the values and change them but it seems to have just made things a lot worse. We are really choppy now and we even get airborne (most likely a weight problem) when we take sudden turns and stops. I also tried to tune the PIDs using PhoneixTunerX but i didnt really know what I was looking for so i tunned them till they responded alright. Also I attempted to Update my pathplanner settings. I will attach a photo if anything looks really wrong please tell me. image 1061×749 31.9 KB

image 1061×749 31.9 KB

image 1061×749 31.9 KB

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
True max speed looks really wrong. You should change your max speed in code too. Also you may down your drive current limit for reducing battery usage.

DukeEmree:

True max speed is likely to be between 4.3 and 5.

Also I don’t undertand your drivetrain behaviour.

If you are manually tuning pid: Screenshot_20250318-085310_Brave 1030×543 80.3 KB

Screenshot_20250318-085310_Brave 1030×543 80.3 KB

Screenshot_20250318-085310_Brave 1030×543 80.3 KB

Also default template should has sysID tests You can find pid and feedforward values automatically.

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: Ok i was able to bring down the PID to around 45 P and around 0.05 D. Should i also look to tune my Kraken X60 for Driving or keep Driving out of this? Also Is it ok for when the robot is not touching the ground the Turn Motors snap to the position given by the Xbox controller and rapidly adjust for the controller.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
I think you should first found true max speed value then turn PID (in my own experience it affect pid values).

Rossj2245:

Should i also look to tune my Kraken X60 for Driving or keep Driving out of this?

Steer and Drive PID not affecting each others. But you should tune both of them especially drive is important I think.

Rossj2245:

Also Is it ok for when the robot is not touching the ground the Turn Motors snap to the position given by the Xbox controller and rapidly adjust for the controller.

Sorry I don’t under stand  what it means. You can set the pid as it does not touch the ground and the motors will come to the position you want.

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: How should I find the max speed?

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
image 1127×536 42 KB You can follow these steps. Also you can calculate it via formula but I have never tried it and I heard it can be inaccurate(I calculated ours and took 85% and the values ​​are very similar so you can try it ).

image 1127×536 42 KB

image 1127×536 42 KB

How to calculate the max free speed of a swerve

Linear Speed ( meters /sec) = motor speed ( RPM ) / gear ratio * pi * wheel diameter ( meters ) / 60

and you should probably get 85% of the value.

link_counts.title: How to calculate the max free speed of a swerve

posts.cooked: My team is currently into issues with pathplanner AutoBuilder. When we made a path to drive the robot in a straight line to the start of the barge zone, it stopped about a foot short of the line. I am curious as to what teams would recommend for Pathplanner Autobuilder PID values?

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Generally p value is between 3-10 I think. Also this issue can persist if you misconfigured your swerve drive.

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: I figured out my issues with the Pathplanner. Now its just my swerve. My Xbox Controller is giving it the raw input of the controller so it keeps jumping around as my thumbstick will never be fully steady.
